content:
2013
												This is more a tech demo than a real game.  Even so, the game aspect is so difficult, I haven't been able to beat a level once.  It uses randomly created levels, in which you have to find 11 objects.  Scattered in the levels are stationary enemy gun turrets, and flying ones as well.  You are provided with 1 of 3 weapons and some ammo, maybe a flashlight.  You can find more ammo in the level, and a few flashlights scattered around as well.Where this "game" shines is in it realistic weapon mechanics.  Guns are treated more as the tools they are than the violent weapons they can be used as.  Reloading my weapon while running from a flying enemy is the most satisfying reload I've had in a game!Several bugs in the game, but hey its a tech demo, what are you gonna do?Worth the money, try it out.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
r 24, 2014
												in Receiver you'll 'receive' a gun (there are different guns) and your main goal is to find audio cassettes (a bit like Slender Man if u will). Automated Turrets and Flying robots are trying to stop you from finding all audio cassettes.Using the gun is pretty realistic, you will have to reload your ammo and check if you got a bullet in the chamber. Also ammo is very scarce and hitting targets is difficult. Failing to take out the turrets and/or robots quickly will result in a quick death, they will attack you with precision and you will die after one or two hits. Everytime you start a new game the map (and audio cassettes) are randomised so that adds to the replay value. For a game that has been made in just 7 days, Receiver is a really good game. Obviously you should not expect a game that will enjoy you for many hours, but the time you spend with this game is well worth it.

ber 19, 2014
												This is Receiver, a game made by Wolfire Games in 7 days for the 7DFPS competition.You are a Receiver."What do you mean by that?" You might think.Okay. You are part of many more other Receivers that dead-dropped cassette tapes all over the place  and you have to pick them up because save the trees.  and you are tasked to listen to the tapes in an unordered fashion to uncover the truth of what happened.The gameplay mechanics are simple and complex at the same time. You are given 1 of 3 guns.The guns in the game are:-Glock 18-Colt 1911-S&W Model 10 "Victory" The tapes were NOT updated when the Glock and the S&W were added, so one of the tapes still considers your weapon to ALWAYS be the 1911. All weapons have realistic ballistics. (AKA bullets fly and ricochet like IRL)Again, you might be thinking "So what?"Well, I'll tell you what. You have to operate specific parts of the gun to be able to even fire a single bullet.Okay, it's not that complicated.For example, the slide, slide release and hammer are different buttons that you have to press to use the gun.You heard that right, kids. The old days of pressing 'R' to reload are over.After a while of figuring out the controls  and dropping all of your magazines  you then have to pick up tapes.Yes, remember back at the start of the guide? TAPES. But to do that, you have to overcome...ENEMIESThere are 2 enemy types in the game.  Both are referred to as 'killdrones' on the tapes. -Turret (Your ordinary stationary turret that swivels and shoots many bullets into you)-Stun Drone (Basically an automated helicopter with a very painful stun gun on it)The catch is that the enemies all have very similar parts, in which way you are able to destroy them.For example, you can put one bullet into the battery and have it dead, or shoot it's main weapon and risk missing and then getting shocked or/and shot.After you recover all of the tapes, you awaken. From what? When did you fall 'asleep'? Play the game and find out.8/10 Great storyline, great gameplay, OK visuals.

content:
2013
												This game is a very entertaining puzzle-shooter that is challenging as hell and insanely intuitive in it's reloading. You actually manually cycle through the entire reloading process and start out with one of three different pistols including an M1911, a revolver and a Glock (I think). You must find ammunition and other equipment yourself, as well as a series of tapes that reveal the story of the game while avoiding security sentries and flying drones. No respawns, no retries for any given scenario. When you die, the scenario changes and everything is relocated. Sometimes you start with multiple full clips and a flash light, others you start with nothing but your gun. Ultimately, this is a fun game to play. Definitely comes highly recommended. Plus, Wolfire Games deserve all the props they can get for being so innovative.

The mechanics and how they apply to the 3 pistols available provide a challenge that takes a short time to learn but a long time to master, or maybe I just suck, who knows? But never the less this game is a highly enjoyable proof of concept type game and worth it's low price.

												One word easily describes this game: thrilling.It's easy enough to imagine what you think you would do a situation Receiver puts you in.  But, for those who have never used a gun, it comes across stressful, dreadful and filled with panic.  And that is was makes this game absolutely fantastic!The idea is simple - you have a gun and off you go.  But it is more a gun simulator than a rouge-like.  Every part of a gun is modelled and must be manipulated to ensure you survive the levels.So most of your time is spent asking questions like, "Is my magazine loaded? Safety off? Is there a round in the chamber? Will it jam? Is there a round in the chamber?".  And by the time you think you've answered those questions you've forgotten to aim and actually shoot the enemy in front.

content:
er 17, 2014
												This game isn't about flashy or fancy graphics, it's about drilling the player on handguns mechanics in the context of a barebones tactical simulator.  As such, the visually bare environment really suits it.  Much more would be less--the game is a work of art in its own right.  The premises and specifics of the storyline are New-Agey (and therefore pretentious, if not ridiculous), but they do provide a context for playing and winning the game.  The ending kinda sucks, but it's really about the journey.The game is challenging.  Ammunition tends to be very limited, especially for the Colt 1911.  It only takes one shot to take you down, but depending upon your shot placement, several rounds may be required to take down a drone or turret.  Player character seems to have brittle bones disease.  If you fall or jump more than a few feet down, you will die. There are no checkpoints or saves. When you die, you have to start all over again in a new, "randomly" generated map, with a "random" loadout of equipment.   You will probably die numerous times before you actually finish the game.   Most of those times, you will probably feel stupid.  Other times, you will be completely out of ammunition, having started with little, having found little, having used what you had efficiently, and having died trying to get more.Game actually succeeded tricked me into listening to recordings of the same  of asinine drivel over and over again, while I thought I was having fun.  Would-be cult leaders and New-Age charlatans take note!I died once because I couldn't make the last step up a flight of stairs.  I tried to run-jump it, bounced backwards, landed at the bottom of the stairs, and died. -4 points for the stair bug.  +3 points for not making me feel like a ninja superhero.For a cheap indie title: 9/10.

content:
ber 16, 2014
												The game's rather... Well I can't say it sucks or isn't worth your time.Due to it's 5 dollar price, I personally think that it's mostly irrelevant if it's any good or not, unlike Gnomoria.The game is listed as an Experimental shooter with drones and turrets and it would be right about that, but just remember, even if the game acts a bit like Slender, The Eight Pages, there is no penalty for picking up the tape recorders.Also nothing will seek you out and kill you, well okay the drones will if they spot you.The game seems to rather accurately mimic how guns actually work, and you get to literally see every bit of most of the basics in how to work a gun, Atleast I would imagine so.There's about 3 guns and they all work differently actually, and each tape you pick up gives a bit of story into the game, and let me tell you, it's honestly rather sweet, almost Matrix-levels of awesome in my opinion. I won't give it away honestly.Coming from a guy who rage quits MOBAs because he sucks at most of them, and does so for weeks at a time, I haven't gotten past 1 tape (which you absorb apparently, atleast according to the game) and have died about 6 times, mostly due to turrets, and once due to a wierd drone that dryhumped my face and apparently shocked me.It is not hard to die in this game. Fall damage will usually always kill you, and I think if shot you will eventually die, even if you get away intact. The game's difficult and would benefit from Razer Hydra control support greatly in my opinion, maybe even some oculus Rift support too, though the difficulty at that point would only increase honestly.Play this game like you would play Dark Souls. Use your brain, observe the patterns of enemies and be stupidly cautious, and I'm sure you won't die as much.It's pretty fun. I've only played 12 minutes but it's still pretty fun.8/10 for a cool and originally executed concept, gun simulation... even if that REALLY needs to exist in alot of other places.Oh, did I mention it works like a Rogue-like game? Nope, I also didn't tell you about fake tapes in the level, or how the tapes don't play the first one, even if it is your first one until the game is reset completely.

content:
y 10, 2015
												For such a simple game, this one's done a great job of keeping my heart pumping quickly. Pros: - The gun mechanics are much more complicated in this game than most, which makes it very unique. Instead of simply pressing "R" to reload a weapon, there is a specific key that is pressed for every step of the reloading process (Removing mag, adding bullets to mag, inserting mag, cocking weapon, etc.). - Your two enemies, Bots and Turrets, both have various hit boxes that, when shot, provide different effects. Turrets, For example, spin around in a circle scanning for the player, and if you fall inside of their sweeping scanner's view, they will fire on you. So shooting a turret in a certian spot may prevent it from spinning, but leave its gun fully operational, and able to shoot you if you walk in front of it; while shooting another location may leave the scanner untouched but render the gun itself useless.- 3 or 4 different guns to choose from that all have different mechanics, strategies, strengths, and weaknesses.- Maps are randomly generated.Cons:- The game is very repetitive. As your goal is always the same: gather the tapes. - Graphics are awkwardly ugly- Lack of enemies/weapons- Slight learning curve for gun mechanics.Overall, keeping the $5 price tag in mind, I give this a 8/10. Honestly I would say it's worth grabbing for the $5 tag if you can get it.

content:
ber 23, 2014
												Receiver, in my opinion, is quite an underrated game.I am, unfortunately, a gun nut, so maybe this game is a bit more enjoyable for me. But this game is underrated imo.When you get put into the game, you'll start off with one of three possible handguns. The Glock, 1911 or a revolver. Initially, you'll realise the controls are a bit hard to get used to. Several different controls for different functions, such as pulling the slide back or checking the chamber.In an hour or two's time, you'll find that you will barely need the help (which you can get by pressing '?', advanced help is holding '?') anymore. You'll also find yourself carefully treading through the map, taking out each bot that you come across quite easily, until one of those damned flying bots get you.There is also a backstory to this game; you pick up tapes and you listen to tips and stories behind the bots and what is real and what isn't. Then, there is also the thing about ammo. I have seen several reviews complaining about ammo; except I never found myself, not even once, in a situation where I have no ammo and am surrounded by enemies. There are many bullets lying about; you just have to look really carefully in corners and under, on top or inside objects. You'll also find yourself properly conserving ammo and knowing which part of the bots to shoot in order to deactivate them.Unfortunately, you die if you get hit even once by anything at all.The realism this game brings is quite astounding, and eventually I became a gunslinger against bots. On record it shows 1.9 hours, but I played more than that. My computer had a meltdown while I was playing it (because I have a not-so-good laptop) and the game accounted to me only 9 minutes of playtime, which, of course, is incorrect.This game is pretty good in general, however, the price is a little bit high. I got it for free on Humble Bundle (also the way I found out about the game). Might not be worth your time if you are into fast-paced action shooting games like Call of Duty.Every. Shot. Counts.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 1, 2014
												FPS with two gimmicks. One, it uses the roguelike paradigm of repeated deaths in a randomized environment. Two, reloading firearms is made much more involved. Rather than the usual r to reload, you have a whole set of actions: remove the magazine, holster your gun, put a bullet in the magazine, take your gun back out, put the magazine back in the gun, undo the slide lock, switch out of automatic.Together these combine in an interesting way. At first, to get anywhere you have to use the help feature, a set of most of your keybindings that highlights what you probably want to do at any given time - especially, what actions you'll have to take to get your gun ready to fire. However after a few hours of play this isn't really needed any more, you've figured it out. Dozens of short plays ending in death tend to do that. It's a nice manual quality; it feels like I've learned to fire a gun in the usual way, practice with my hands.This was almost certainly intended by the game makers. The scarce plot serves as justification for the main goal, finding tapes to listen to in order for your character to become "awakened" to the true Gnostic reality, which has been obscured from humanity at large by the "Threat". One tape in particular tells the character that they have been mentally weakened by popular media for years, and that the tapes are only a small step. The only way to escape the destructive Threat influence is by finding all the tapes, _and listening to them repeatedly_ (a million times is the suggestion).There's a minor suggestion that the player is themselves in a deeper layer of the Gnostic heap, only able to get these messages from true reality through fiction. Considering the gun learning process, and that you will listen to the tapes repeatedly over your playthroughs, the intent is I think clear.So that's neat. Of course all games do this learning to some extent, but it's interesting to see it more or less explicitly mentioned, and applying to something more "real world" than laying out character stats or something. (At least, I think real guns work mostly like in Receiver? I haven't touched one in years...) Of course I'd prefer if the skills taught were something other than firearms but what can you do.The game does have problems. The graphics are primitive and glitches are apparent; for example you can jump through the ceiling in a few areas. More importantly I think, the game is pretty small. It was made in a week or such like and the lack of content shows. There are a limited number of room layouts that are spliced together to form your environment and it gets repetitive, and there are only two types of enemies. There's a load time between some rooms, that freezes the game for a few seconds; the resulting disorientation has gotten me killed many times.It's definitely worth the less-than-ten-bucks however.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
7, 2016
												How would you do if you had to control your weapon the same way as you do in real life? Would you be able to reload in time to shoot what is coming at you? Would you even be able to remember how to put the magazine back in without scattering precious unspent bullets all over the floor?Excellent for shooter mechanics. Unparalleled, actually. Because of this game, I want all shooters to have a mod that brings this game's gun mechanics in.Not much else to keep you playing though. Oh, there's a mod that adds some more guns. Needs multiplayer. And, you know, more stuff to do then the same ~ten "rooms" and two enemies.

content:
er 28, 2016
												I got this game for $2.99 with my mind set on an hour of something to do, oh boy were I in for a treat.THIS. ♥♥♥♥ING. GAME.SO SIMPLE I LOVE IT.Fun game that changes the way you play FPS games. The game has 3 different guns that you spawn with randomly. A Glock 17, Colt Handgun and a S&W Revolver. These do all have different mechanics to them.This game is so original, and you aren't believing me right now I get that, but just hear me out.Instead of just pushing "R" for reloading, you have to: Press one key to detach the mag..Another key to load the mag with bullets.. (AND YOU NEED TO FIND THOSE SEPARATELY) Another key to put the mag in the gun..And yet another one to drag the slide and load the first bullet into the chamber..And trust me when I say this.. This is some real butt clenching stuff when you realize you're out of bullets and a ♥♥♥♥ing flying taser gun are chasing you. (I'm not making this up..)Oh.. and the gun can also jam on you.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
8, 2015
												Receiver manages to create a dark sci-fi setting with the use of a few short tape recordings. The game itself focuses on detailed gun manipulation that turn the automated actions of reloading, swapping mags or just checking how much ammo you got left, into detailed keystrokes that can end in disaster if used wrong in a combat situation. This is a great basis to give the game a lot of replayability even though it only features 3 weapons and two types of enemies as, like in a good action puzzler, your precise timing and situational awarness are tested over and over again even if you played through it before. The randomized layout and placement of enemies and pickups further adds to the replaybility of the title.If you are not turned down by perma-death and the inability to safe or load a gamestate and you have a soft spot for punishing first-person action combined with a fresh look at gun play, this might be the title for you.

There are a limited number of room layouts that are spliced together to form your environment and it gets repetitive, and there are only two types of enemies. There's a load time between some rooms, that freezes the game for a few seconds; the resulting disorientation has gotten me killed many times.It's definitely worth the less-than-ten-bucks however.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
8, 2015
												Highly visceral and deep gun handling and creepy distopian vibe are the two primary positive elements that this game has to offer. Nothing beats the feeling of learning the gun mechanics and successfully using them against the (sadly) 2 types of enemies you'll face during the game.The map is randomly generated for each playthrough and each time you die but things will definitely start to look familiar the more you play. Your mission is to locate 11 tapes that are scattered around the map and listen to their dialogue while staying alive. Be very careful while turning each corner in this game because a single enemy shot will kill you and send you back to the beginning. Oh and did I mention the guns are also randomized? There are 3 guns total but how many bullets they have and whether they're loaded, cocked or with the safety on can vary between each start.On the negative side, there are framerate hitches whenever you walk into new areas and the levels can get really dark. The flashlight proved more of a nuisance than help because it only lights up a few feet in front of you. This could mean life or death in this game. There are no gamma settings in the game. Also, as I mentioned previously, the levels can get a bit repetitive at times because they are seemingly different pre-made areas which are stitched together in different ways because of the level generator.All in all, a very entertaining game. Definitely get this on a sale. The adrenaline rush and realistic gun handling are definitely worth quite a few hours of random fun.

												Receiver manages to create a dark sci-fi setting with the use of a few short tape recordings. The game itself focuses on detailed gun manipulation that turn the automated actions of reloading, swapping mags or just checking how much ammo you got left, into detailed keystrokes that can end in disaster if used wrong in a combat situation. This is a great basis to give the game a lot of replayability even though it only features 3 weapons and two types of enemies as, like in a good action puzzler, your precise timing and situational awarness are tested over and over again even if you played through it before. The randomized layout and placement of enemies and pickups further adds to the replaybility of the title.If you are not turned down by perma-death and the inability to safe or load a gamestate and you have a soft spot for punishing first-person action combined with a fresh look at gun play, this might be the title for you.

												It's free on the Humble Store right now if you feel like grabbing it.Otherwise I can't recommend buying it. Basically, you walk around getting casette tapes where then a man narrates some gibberish, giving context to the scenario, a la Bioshock. But the difference here is that Receiver is trying to simulate using a gun via keyboard and mouse by forcing you to press something like four different keys just to eject the forking ammo. And while trying to listen to the tapes while walking around the single, randomly generated level, you'll probably get shot by a turret and die.Speaking of the randomly generated level, it's aesthetically awkward. It' one kind of big level where you randomly respawn after dying so many times and you don't retain your tapes. So when the motion and visual detecting turrets gun you down over and over again, don't blame yourself.6.0/10

number of helpful: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
6, 2014
												Well holy sheeeet. That was a damn good game.The core concept of the game is, "What if using a gun in an FPS was as complicated a process as it is in real life?" and that boils down to each little part of the gun having it's own button associated with it. You don't just tap the R button and watch a cool little animation and then be on your way, you have to do all the little things required and in the right order as your situation dictates. At the start you will fumble around with the gun functions and may not even figure out how to shoot for quite a while. Then after a few minutes you may start to get the hang of it, albeit taking your time between shots. After a few hours of playing you will really get the hang of things and reloading will be like clockwork.Even the enemies, which are little robots, have a similar complexity to them. They don't just have an HP bar that empties out after a few shots. You have to hit them in very specific parts to disable certain functions of them until you can safely pass by. It's up to you to learn where your shots count the most for disabling them.The world is rather bland, however, and consists of a bunch of randomly generated rooms in sequence. You will get very used to these room as there is very little variety between them. You will figure out pretty quickly where the ammo drops can be and where the robots can be placed in certain rooms. It's the only real flaw in the game.The music is decent and gives a proper mood to the whole thing.One odd thing to note about the game is that you have to go to a separate website to patch the game. Specifically here[forums.wolfire.com]. Otherwise the game run's very poorly I've heard. I've only played the game patched and it is recommended.If you are someone who want's a score then I give the game 5 cassette tapes out 5. Nothing significantly hinders the enjoyment of the game and the core concept is pulled of splendidly.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 27, 2014
												Receiver is a game about shooting....Oh, were you looking for something else? That pretty much sums up what this game is, from it's concept, of course. Now, let's start the real review:Graphics: Made in Unity 3D, the game has simple graphics and places that seems to be missing textures. But it's all part of the game's visual art style and concept. Enemies desing are also pretty simple and you can spot then on sight (Witch is essential in this game IMO). I guess the gun model is okay, since it gives player a good vision of what he's doing with it and where he's REALLY poiting at. Skybox is dead, but you really don't need it in this game.Gameplay: This is the jackpot in this game. The realism put into shooting, reloading, carrying and using your gun is something so nice to see in a FPS and that even most AAA studios keep forgetting that it exists. Playing this game using the device that simulates a pistol is even better. All the controls, from the keyboard/mouse/device responds pretty well and always keeps the game fluid and dinamic.Even tough gunplay is the biggest part of this game, it also haves an objective: Collecting all your self recordings so you can finish the game. But finding then is a pain in the ♥♥♥. Not only you don't have a radar, but you will die a ♥♥♥♥ING lot in this game. It IS hard. And i mean it. The enemies were created with the intetion of making the game hard in this way, and the AI woks pretty well to make sure that this is happening. Don't mess with the enemies. It's not because the game is realistic that the enemies will also be. 2-3 shoots and you are dead. Make sure of always keeping your ammo at count, or else, you are ♥♥♥♥ed.Soundtrack: Missing. Even tough the self recording are pretty neat to hear, i just can't like this monotunus atmosphere. They could've put some songs like The Stanley Parable did (Or SuperHot) to don't let the player attention go away of the game. Mostly because that if you are not paying attention, you are dead.Story: Most of it is explained through recordings. It's not a gigantic plot, but it does it job of keeping the player guessing. Going through uncovering the secrets of the protagonist organization and himself is quite awesome and it has a nice progression...When you find then in order, that's because the only bad thing is: If you die, your found recording count will reset, so, if you want to find a new one that you haven't heard yet/don't want to hear the same thing again from a past one, good luck with that.This game is more considered a "project" than a game itself. It had a nice proporsal and the idea of this game can be explored in other games (Indie or AAA). If you are looking to experience something new and a neat challenge, Receiver is a "game" for you.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
4, 2014
												I have to voice how impressed I am with this one. I thought this was going to be a quick pick-up-and-play novelty, but instead I found a game with an extremely complex and deep gun mechanic.Good:The main catch of Receiver is that it has some seriously detailed and realistic gun mechanics. You randomly start with one of three pistols, either a magnum pistol, a revolver, or an automatic handgun, in a random state with a random amount of bullets. The term 'check your weapon' seriously applies here. How many bullets are in the magazine? Is there a bullet in the chamber? Do I need to pull the slide back? Is the safety on? Is it in automatic? Each of these questions comes up each time you spawn and pick up your gun, and each function and action has a key you have to memorize.But what really keeps getting me about this game is how creepy it is. You are, in essence, the only living thing in a randomly generated complex filled with cold robots. it is dark and almost eerie. I kept thinking to myself that this game would make an incredible horror game. This is what F.E.A.R. should have been. But, as is, it is overall very tense and does a good job of leaving a lasting impression despite being so simple in story and graphics.I should also mention this game is very difficult in a lot of ways. You will likely die fumbling around with your pistol and trying to remember the controls. You'll curse yourself for accidentally dropping your magazine when you are trying to reload it, or while you scramble for that perfectly good bullet you ejected from your gun on accident. But the feeling of mastering your pistol is truly a reward on its own. And that doesn't even include shooting things.Enemies are tough on that note. Robots don't die from just being shot a lot. Enemy bots have four vitals you can hit to kill or disable them: weapon, motor, battery, and camera. Precision is everything. One aimed pistol shot can render a robot useless, but madly firing at the main body will do nothing. Turrets will unleash a flurry of machinegun fire if they catch glimpse of you, and those shock drones are a whole lot faster than they look. And finally, you die in one hit, and must start over every time you are killed.But its all good challenge, and while the complex appears to be nearly infinite, it is possible to learn the game, recognize certain consistent features, and fight off your attackers with deadly skill while you explore and search for tapes.So, overall for the good, it has a deep gun mechanic with lots of nuances and details (which is rare that I actually like something like this), its a lot more challenging than it looks, and somehow manages to master the art of simple elegance and proficent story telling while still being very simplistic.Bad:I really don't like some of the randomization. One time I started within easy view of a hover drone, and prompty got zapped before I could even check my gun out. Another time I started with only two bullets in my gun and nothing else. Often times I found myself going on forever; searching out the complex without finding any of the tapes for long periods of time. A little consistency and a safe zone to start with would have been nice.Also, I have to say while this game is fun, I feel like it is also a game I will never be able to beat. The complex is absolutely huge. I sometimes would spend several minutes gunning down robots and trying to survive; only to die with not even one tape. A radar for the little things would have been nice. Or something more than just a shiny spot. Its fun to be able to just explore blindly and figure things out on your own, but only to an extent. This goes well past that extent and into the frustrating "I can't figure out how to beat this" zone.Maybe that's part of the challenge for some, but that's not really my thing as a casual gamer.Also, you'll learn to hate the hover drones because of how derpy their movements are. It really looks like they are being held up by a string. They bob and wobble in the air like a balloon in the wind, and will bounce and flop all over the floors and walls whenever they try to charge you. Again, maybe that's part of the challenge, but those things really test the aim in a bad way.Finally, the game does tend to lag a bit in certain areas, which for a game where victory depends on quick reflexes and sharp aim, that is really just a killer. I hate to walk through a door, only to have a lag spike that leads me to getting shot by an enemy I couldn't see around the corner.So, while the game is fun, I do feel like there were a few flaws in execution. The randomness would be fine if your task wasn't so tedious and the level so massive. Aspects that I felt like should be there to legitimately challenge me just kept rubbing off on me the wrong way.Finally, I will say that a way to choose which gun you start with would have been a fun feature, and I can't figure any reason why this had to be excluded.But, overall, I don't think any of that dampened the experience I had enough for me to not recommend this.Its a good challenge and a bit of a mind teaser as far as the controls go. There's a lot of detail that is sure to please any gun enthusiast out there, or just anyone who wants a break from the usual FPS crazies out there. It may not be the most realistic gun simulator, but it does an excellent job at simulating the feel of real combat. It teaches you how precious a bullet really is, why aiming is so important, and how ridiculous all the other action games like Call of Duty really are when it comes to their gunplay. Its immersive, its intense, and its a whole lot of fun.Its a bit of an experiment that I'm sure won't please everyone, but the idea is solid and the feelings it established really caught me by surprise. At the very least, this game is sure to teach you why weapons training is so much more important than learning to pull the trigger. And for this price? I couldn't recommend it more.

												Receiver is for those people who like a fast adventure thats different every time and/or people who love gun mechanics. The game is very basic on graphics, but its honestly a good game.Replayability is high as item spawns, enemies and the entire map are random each time. The story is very basic and once you've heard all the tapes the story is not exactly always refreshing.Even though there are only 3 weapons they cover all the basic means of handguns. The Revolver, the medium handgun, the light handgun and even the automatic (On the glock). it allows you to make strategies based on what you like the most, being that all guns have their own ups and downs. This is both in rate of fire, capacity and power. Accuracy and range aren't issues at all thay you'll deal with as the environments you'll be fighting in usually force you to be within 100 yards away from enemies.The enemies are very basic, but they cover conventional standards; one can move and attack while the other one can shoot but not move.(and if your wondering why I only have 0.3 hours its because I took it off of my computer and played it at work)Overall rating: 8/10 Well worth the price.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
4, 2014
												I have to voice how impressed I am with this one. I thought this was going to be a quick pick-up-and-play novelty, but instead I found a game with an extremely complex and deep gun mechanic.Good:The main catch of Receiver is that it has some seriously detailed and realistic gun mechanics. You randomly start with one of three pistols, either a magnum pistol, a revolver, or an automatic handgun, in a random state with a random amount of bullets. The term 'check your weapon' seriously applies here. How many bullets are in the magazine? Is there a bullet in the chamber? Do I need to pull the slide back? Is the safety on? Is it in automatic? Each of these questions comes up each time you spawn and pick up your gun, and each function and action has a key you have to memorize.But what really keeps getting me about this game is how creepy it is. You are, in essence, the only living thing in a randomly generated complex filled with cold robots. it is dark and almost eerie. I kept thinking to myself that this game would make an incredible horror game. This is what F.E.A.R. should have been. But, as is, it is overall very tense and does a good job of leaving a lasting impression despite being so simple in story and graphics.I should also mention this game is very difficult in a lot of ways. You will likely die fumbling around with your pistol and trying to remember the controls. You'll curse yourself for accidentally dropping your magazine when you are trying to reload it, or while you scramble for that perfectly good bullet you ejected from your gun on accident. But the feeling of mastering your pistol is truly a reward on its own. And that doesn't even include shooting things.Enemies are tough on that note. Robots don't die from just being shot a lot. Enemy bots have four vitals you can hit to kill or disable them: weapon, motor, battery, and camera. Precision is everything. One aimed pistol shot can render a robot useless, but madly firing at the main body will do nothing. Turrets will unleash a flurry of machinegun fire if they catch glimpse of you, and those shock drones are a whole lot faster than they look. And finally, you die in one hit, and must start over every time you are killed.But its all good challenge, and while the complex appears to be nearly infinite, it is possible to learn the game, recognize certain consistent features, and fight off your attackers with deadly skill while you explore and search for tapes.So, overall for the good, it has a deep gun mechanic with lots of nuances and details (which is rare that I actually like something like this), its a lot more challenging than it looks, and somehow manages to master the art of simple elegance and proficent story telling while still being very simplistic.Bad:I really don't like some of the randomization. One time I started within easy view of a hover drone, and prompty got zapped before I could even check my gun out. Another time I started with only two bullets in my gun and nothing else. Often times I found myself going on forever; searching out the complex without finding any of the tapes for long periods of time. A little consistency and a safe zone to start with would have been nice.Also, I have to say while this game is fun, I feel like it is also a game I will never be able to beat. The complex is absolutely huge. I sometimes would spend several minutes gunning down robots and trying to survive; only to die with not even one tape. A radar for the little things would have been nice. Or something more than just a shiny spot. Its fun to be able to just explore blindly and figure things out on your own, but only to an extent. This goes well past that extent and into the frustrating "I can't figure out how to beat this" zone.Maybe that's part of the challenge for some, but that's not really my thing as a casual gamer.Also, you'll learn to hate the hover drones because of how derpy their movements are. It really looks like they are being held up by a string. They bob and wobble in the air like a balloon in the wind, and will bounce and flop all over the floors and walls whenever they try to charge you. Again, maybe that's part of the challenge, but those things really test the aim in a bad way.Finally, the game does tend to lag a bit in certain areas, which for a game where victory depends on quick reflexes and sharp aim, that is really just a killer. I hate to walk through a door, only to have a lag spike that leads me to getting shot by an enemy I couldn't see around the corner.So, while the game is fun, I do feel like there were a few flaws in execution. The randomness would be fine if your task wasn't so tedious and the level so massive. Aspects that I felt like should be there to legitimately challenge me just kept rubbing off on me the wrong way.Finally, I will say that a way to choose which gun you start with would have been a fun feature, and I can't figure any reason why this had to be excluded.But, overall, I don't think any of that dampened the experience I had enough for me to not recommend this.Its a good challenge and a bit of a mind teaser as far as the controls go. There's a lot of detail that is sure to please any gun enthusiast out there, or just anyone who wants a break from the usual FPS crazies out there. It may not be the most realistic gun simulator, but it does an excellent job at simulating the feel of real combat. It teaches you how precious a bullet really is, why aiming is so important, and how ridiculous all the other action games like Call of Duty really are when it comes to their gunplay. Its immersive, its intense, and its a whole lot of fun.Its a bit of an experiment that I'm sure won't please everyone, but the idea is solid and the feelings it established really caught me by surprise. At the very least, this game is sure to teach you why weapons training is so much more important than learning to pull the trigger. And for this price? I couldn't recommend it more.

content:
ber 28, 2014
												Receiver is not a game that everyone will like. It takes the FPS genre to a much higher level of realism. It has no difficulty settings, checkpoints, game save or HUD for that matter.You start the game in a random room inside of a building. You don´t know who you are or why you´re there. Equipped with a 1 of 3 diferent firearms (a Glock 18, a Revolver or a 1911 45. cal Pistol), a flashlight(that you may not get on spawn but be able to find later), and nothing else than that you must find out what is going on.When walking around the building you will find  turrets or flying robots that will try to kill you. You can fight or run, but in some areas you will just have to go trough them to progress. You will eventually find orange sound tapes that will tell you why you´re there, how to get out, and how to effectively fight the robots and turrets. In order to finish the game you must find all 11 tapes scattered around the building.The game mechanics will be hard to understand at 1st, but in time you will get better at it. And if you don´t like some of the controls you can change them from the Launch Menu.You don´t have sights in the screen so you must aim to shoot properly, there are many commands for what you can do with your weapon, and the reload process must be done manually.Ammo is in pretty short supply, so you got to look around in the building and find bullets, equip it in your magazine (or barrel) and put in your inventory(in case you are using a pistol), then have it ready to reload in combat.Also this game is made with the Unity engine, so don´t expect anything fancy here.

												This game is extremely fun and challenging little game that will put your memory and mouse handling skills to the test!Not only does this game have a very eerie atmosphere and creepy story but the realism around the guns are very well done. The shooting feels nice and feels very rewarding when you hear that *dink* and *crash* that means you succesfully took out an enemy. I learn quickly so the controls were not a problem. But without the little "Help" tap on the left I would have been hopeless. Which is also very well done!The one thing I really love is also that you can disable your enemies without destroying them. Like shooting the gun on the automatic turret and stading infront of it to check if it really is disabled is really nerveracking because a shot to the foot and you're dead. I also love the "OH ♥♥♥♥" feeling you get when the gyrocopter spots you and you're out of ammo.All in all 8/10 could do with some optimization and a nerf to the flying bots! By the way, check out the developers other game; Overgrowth which is also fantastic!

												Sort of an FPS roguelike, you basically just wander and wander and wander looking for tapes and ammo, with no maps or any other clues to help you at all.I enjoyed the realistc gun operation, even though it got me killed many many times.There's basically 2 kinds of enemies, turrets and flybots, and both can 1-shot you, which can lead to some frustration. On top of that, there's barely enough ammo to get by, and if you wander into the wrong spot and get spotted by a flybot and waste your last few bullets on it, its almost a guaranteed GG.I eventually got bored of just randering around an RNG building, and fortunately there were some cheats available.Even with invincibility and unlimited ammo, the game was STILL a hassle to complete. I'd spin around and empty 3-4 magazines trying to shoot 1 little drone buzzing around my head.Eventually the game just started trolling and put 3 tapes and 5 turrets in a very small space. I have NO idea how I would have gotten past that without infinite ammo.I don't know if I would pay $5 for this, but it's definitely an interesting little time waster.

content:
ry 27, 2014
												Receiver is a game about shooting....Oh, were you looking for something else? That pretty much sums up what this game is, from it's concept, of course. Now, let's start the real review:Graphics: Made in Unity 3D, the game has simple graphics and places that seems to be missing textures. But it's all part of the game's visual art style and concept. Enemies desing are also pretty simple and you can spot then on sight (Witch is essential in this game IMO). I guess the gun model is okay, since it gives player a good vision of what he's doing with it and where he's REALLY poiting at. Skybox is dead, but you really don't need it in this game.Gameplay: This is the jackpot in this game. The realism put into shooting, reloading, carrying and using your gun is something so nice to see in a FPS and that even most AAA studios keep forgetting that it exists. Playing this game using the device that simulates a pistol is even better. All the controls, from the keyboard/mouse/device responds pretty well and always keeps the game fluid and dinamic.Even tough gunplay is the biggest part of this game, it also haves an objective: Collecting all your self recordings so you can finish the game. But finding then is a pain in the ♥♥♥. Not only you don't have a radar, but you will die a ♥♥♥♥ING lot in this game. It IS hard. And i mean it. The enemies were created with the intetion of making the game hard in this way, and the AI woks pretty well to make sure that this is happening. Don't mess with the enemies. It's not because the game is realistic that the enemies will also be. 2-3 shoots and you are dead. Make sure of always keeping your ammo at count, or else, you are ♥♥♥♥ed.Soundtrack: Missing. Even tough the self recording are pretty neat to hear, i just can't like this monotunus atmosphere. They could've put some songs like The Stanley Parable did (Or SuperHot) to don't let the player attention go away of the game. Mostly because that if you are not paying attention, you are dead.Story: Most of it is explained through recordings. It's not a gigantic plot, but it does it job of keeping the player guessing. Going through uncovering the secrets of the protagonist organization and himself is quite awesome and it has a nice progression...When you find then in order, that's because the only bad thing is: If you die, your found recording count will reset, so, if you want to find a new one that you haven't heard yet/don't want to hear the same thing again from a past one, good luck with that.This game is more considered a "project" than a game itself. It had a nice proporsal and the idea of this game can be explored in other games (Indie or AAA). If you are looking to experience something new and a neat challenge, Receiver is a "game" for you.

												I found this game to be both interesting and challenging.The game consists primarily of traversing randomly generated building complex filled with randomly generated enemies and items. As far as I can tell, the goal seems to be to find 11 cassette tapes scattered around the complex. While doing this this, you must protect yourself from enemies using one of three firearms: the Colt 1911A1, a Glock 18C, or a Revolver (not sure what make or model, as I'm not a gun expert).The weapon mechanics as unique in that you have control over the slide, saftey, fire rate, magazine eject and loading, magizine refilling, and other various aspects.While that can seem daunting, you have a helpful guide available at all times to help you with each mechanic. I personally found it quite satisfiying when I was able to refill a magazine, replace my empty one and pull back the slide all from memory while franticlly running from a drone bent on chasing me down.The enemies themselves are simple and limited in terms of variety, but that doesn't make the any less deadly.You have stationary turrets which will rotate 360 degrees around them, capable of looking both up and down, and have a pretty far range of detection.The second and final enemy are flying drones that typically will hover in place, slowly rotating around untill they see you. Once they do, they then blindly charge at you, ready to hit you with a extremly (thankfully) short range taser.If that doesn't seem to difficult, the fact that a single touch from either a bullet, or the taser will kill you imediately.Oh, and there's fall damage. That'll kill you too.The upside to everything being randomly generated is that it keeps the game fresh and challenging. You can't memorize where everything is or exploit the map. The downside is that the difficultly can fluctuate extremely. Your weapon is randomly given to you, as well as starting ammo and other equipment. Where you start is random, as well as the number and location of enemies.You could spawn in a room with maybe seven bullets, have no items to collect anywhere near you, and have four turrets and five flying drones in the next room.Or you could have a moderate amount ammo, plenty more around you, and few enemies to deal with.Or you could spawn directly in front of a turret. That happens too.Put simply:Pros:-Fun weapon mechanics-Challenging yet simple enemies-Player only has two hands, and thus can't do things that require them having more than two hands.-Small file size-Limited supplies and high vunerability require decision making and planning-Randomly generated map keeps gameplay unique and challengeingCons:-Randomly generated map leads to massive spikes in difficulty-Player can die extremely easy. Possibly could have had something to make them slightly more durable, even temporarily- Game tends to freeze momentarily when loading more of the mapTL;DRI shot a drone seven times only to run out of ammo and have it chase me back across the map while I screamed like a girl8/10 Would ♥♥♥♥ myself again

content:
, 2015
												If you want the short n' quick of my review, here it is: It's an incredibly challenging game with an extremely well-made gun mechanic and great immersion, but it's poorly optimized and variety is limited.When I first picked up this game I had no idea what I was doing, and I think I quite enjoyed that at first, the first few deaths were absolutely laughable as I fumbled around with the controls manually looking up which button does what every time I needed to load another bullet or try to pick up a tape. The first thing you notice are that the graphics are mediocre at best, but in a game like this it really doesn't hurt the immersion factor one bit. The immersion is amazing, by the way. This game is an unintentional survival horror game. Enemies can and WILL scare the ♥♥♥♥ outta you.But then after a little while I got a hang of the controls, and that's where things really picked up. After you start to get proficient at controlling the gun and even the more advanced mechanics of switching out whole mags quickly instead of just reloading a few bullets, the game gets immensely more involved. You're no longer concerned with just getting one or two tapes, you want them all. You want them bad, you've already spent several hours on this thing... So you start to learn the very well-implemented mechanics of localized damaging, where you need to hit a specific part of an enemy to take it out, and with as few bullets as possible. No CoD-style shooting at someones hands or legs to damage them.The voice acting is not great, he fumbles around with words a bit and sometimes the sound clips a bit, but it doesn't matter because given the story it's totally reasonable for this. Story-wise: They might not have had enough time to record a super-fancy nice message. Development wise, they only had a week. Cut em' some slack.Eventually, you get to the point where you've heard every tape a dozen times and seen every enemy almost every time, and you still may not have beaten the game because there are so many ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ tapes. At this point, there's a very real possibility that you could get tired of the game due to the lack of variety and extreme difficulty. But, if you persevere, and there's a good chance that you'll beat it, and oh boy... When you beat it, it's so satisfying. INCREDIBLY satisfying.On top of all that there's actually a good bit of replay value thanks to the randomization of all the maps (Though it admittedly can ♥♥♥♥ you up someimtes and it's entirely possible to have an impossible-to-beat map) and even the modding community that has managed to add in a bunch of different stuff to make the game play better.So to recap!Pros:+ Great gun mechanics+ Accurate gun and bullet physics+ Randomization of structures item locations+ Reasonable learning curve+ Amazing immersion+ Very satisfying to finally beat+ Good replay value+ Great modding communityCons:- Very poor textures even on highest settings- Poor optimization due to engine limitations- Only 2 gun types by default- Only 2 types of enemies- Borderline extreme difficulty to get all 11 tapes (At least for me),  meaning it can take a long time to beat with a lot of potential frustration.- Randomization can ♥♥♥♥ you overOverall I would definitely recommend this game. It's an impressive and fun to play twist on the FPS genre made in only a week.

content:
2, 2013
												Most games assign you a single button to reload your gun. Most games provide you enough ammo to get the job done. Most games start you with the same equipment, in the same location on the map. Receiver is not most games.You start with one of three weapons at a random location on the single, large map. The amount of ammo you have appears to be random, as does whether or not you have a flashlight or spare magazines. In a normal FPS, you'd start with a full clip and pressing "fire" would do just that. With Receiver, that would make you extremely lucky. The first thing to do is examine your weapon. Is it a revolver, a semi-automatic, or a machine pistol? Is it loaded? How full is the magazine? Is the safety on? Is it set to full auto? All of this matters.While this can sound tedious, the surprising thing about Receiver is that it works. The graphics are terrible, the sound and story are nothing to write home about, but the gameplay more than makes up for everything else. As frustrating as the first few rounds can be, it's extremely rewarding when you finally start to pick things up. You'll quickly learn to count your shots because you don't have an ammo counter. You'll quickly learn to take cover and look around corners because the enemies are lethal. Pretty soon checking your gun, loading your magazines when you get ammo and checking every corner for turrets will be second nature.

content:
20, 2014
												[Pros]-Interesting sci-fi story. You are a "Receiver", one of the very few people who are able to hear a voice inside different mysterious cassettes you find. You must find enough cassettes to "escape" MindKill.This sound a lot like Matrix, and yes, it is something like that.-The unique gameplay mechanic of the game: It simulate a more realistic way to control a pistol. Specifically a Colt 1911 pistol, a S&W Model 10 "Victory" revolver, and a Glock 17.At first it is VERY complicate to remember every single button to control succesfully a pistol, but with enough practice, you can master it.-The game offer you a very helpful guide which show you the action of each button. A huge plus in my opinion.-The whole game take place in one huge level. However all the rooms/places, bullets, cassettes, enemies and the pistol you using is random generated every single time. Something like a Rogue game in other words.-The feeling controlling successfully a gun by pushing the keys in the rights order, is unbelievable! Me neither believed it at first, but it is true!!!-The A.I of the enemies is very interesting, specifically the flying drone. One time a flying drone hit a wall while I was running to avoid it. The result was to get disfunctioning and the drone started flying around like a drunk! Hilarious!!!!One another time I shoot a drone and fall down just only to discover when I approached it was still functioning and killed me!!! MotherF*cker!!!!The same goes of course for the gun turrets you fight/avoid in the game.[Cons]-The whole game is only one level. That it. Nothing new to add or a New Game Plus mode.-Only two enemies types: The flying drones and the gun turrets. More enemies would made the game even better.-Very difficult start. Even if I said it is very enjoyable to master the pistols, you will "suffer" a little to play the game properly.-My main reason why I gave the game 9/10 stars:If you enter a new room/place, suddenly the game freeze a little for an unknown reason. For this many times I died because gun turrets shot me while I was lagged entering a room....[Final Thought]Being very Cheap on Steam right now, it is a must play just only for the unique experience is offer.It have some problems, but I forgive them very easily.I hope for a better and bigger sequel in the future.9/10

There's a reason no other shooter has realistic reloading, and it's not the fault of the games, it's the limitations of the keyboard/controller. It's the same reason flight sims can be tedious when played on a keyboard. For a game made in a short amount of time, sure, it's not bad. But that's about it.

content:
2, 2015
												I would recommend this game to just about anybody who is a fan of the first-person shooter genre or has any kind of interest in guns. This well crafted gun simulator is, like they say, easy to learn but hard to master. Learning each weapon and how it is operated by muscle memory is fluid and satisfying; I never tired of loading and charging a weapon.The minimalistic presentation of the game environment allows the gun to be the focus of the game, as it should be, but each section in the procedurally generated world has its own challenges and secrets. After some practice you will grow well versed in traversing these environments and scanning them for threats and loot, which brings its own satisfaction.Perhaps the most satisfying of all the game's elements is its actual combat. Enemies come in two types: hovering taser drones and static turrets, both of which can deliver instant and fatal damage to the player. The gameplay here is challenging, but never unfair, and the quick restarts allow you to dive straight back into the game and apply what you've learned from past mistakes. The trial-and-error nature of Receiver's gameplay gives it a visceral and ephemeral feel comparable to that of Hotline Miami, although with a vastly different tone.Like the rest of the game, Receiver's story is delivered in a minimalistic and really quite interpretive style. You are tasked with exploring the world and collecting all eleven casette tapes, which contain a wealth of esoteric knowledge, accessible only to the specially mentally conditioned, known of course as 'receivers'. Despite their monotone delivery, I never really became bored with the tapes even after repeated listens. By the time you have heard all eleven, you will have memorised a great deal of background story information, which gives the feeling that you are a receiver. The casettes mention important story threads such as 'the Threat', 'the Mindkill' and multiple realities with such passing apathy that one is forced to imagine what exactly they entail, making the story that much more interesting. Without so much being left to the imagination, the game's story could not have had nearly the same effect.All told, Receiver is a simple but beautiful game. Its developers set out to create in seven days an engaging and accurate gun simulator with minimalist storytelling and they have succeeded by all measures. Receiver is a cheap buy and well worth a look from a fan of the shooting genre.

content:
25, 2016
												This game is very crafty and all of the spawns, from rooms to what you spawn with, are randomized. The game very quickly teaches you to be cautious, ranging from punishing you for running into a room without looking into it first, to immediately being rammed in the side with a drone with no way to counter against it.How enemies spawn is randomized, and sometimes a bunch of turrets will be spawned in such a way that you'll need to tactfully take out each one before you can move on, and sometimes it'll cluster 5 turrets in one room.To keep you on your toes, how quickly you can react to turrets seeing you varies, ranging from being able to be seen by a turret for a full second and not die, to being shot the instant you enter their field of vision.Additionally, it seems how durable the robots are is also randomized. For example, sometime's you'll take out 4 enemies with one shot each, and sometimes you'll have to dump 10 bullets into a turret's weakpoint before it stops moving.What you spawn with is randomized, which means sometimes you can spawn with a revolver and 30 bullets, and sometimes you'll spawn with a M1911A1 and 4 bullets.Where you spawn is also randomized. Sometimes you'll spawn in a room full of ammo and maybe a tape and/or flashlight, and sometimes you'll spawn in direct view of a turret.Don't get me wrong, this is a great game, it's just that if you're purchasing this, prepare for RNGesus to kick you in the butt. A lot.

content:
ry 13, 2014
												Receiver can only be described as a gun simulator. The combat is nothing special; right-click to aim with a small deadzone and left-click to fire. But what makes it a notable experiment in video gaming is the act of reloading. It's nothing so simple as pressing R and waiting for an animation to play out; you have to press a button for almost every action involved.When you first spawn in, you need to check your firearm. There are buttons to pull back (and then lock) the slide, toggle the safety, (de-)♥♥♥♥ the hammer, remove the magazine, place the magazine in a specific inventory slot, remove a magazine from a specific inventory slot, holster the firearm, and load individual rounds into magazines.If you can master the art of firing a shot, dropping the mag, holstering the firearm, reloading the magazine, redrawing the firearm, replacing the magazine, and (just for good measure) hitting the bolt release, you'll more than likely get a tingly sensation after doing it. This is hands-on gun porn.The rest of the game is pretty basic; textures are a luxury, geometry is flat and neutral, the atmosphere is eerie in a Deus-Ex way, and the lore behind the recordings is rather interesting. Combat is tense and calculated, much more akin to chess than boxing, but sometimes the rules aren't clear enough to ease your frustration every time you die.In the end, I'd love to see more games like this for more firearms, if only as an instruction tool for people wanting to learn how to use firearms without access to any or proper instruction.7/10 - I came 9mm.

content:
er 27, 2013
												Have I been waiting for a game like this for the last 10 years of my life?Yes.Does this game make you feel bad ♥♥♥?Yes.Can you complete it?Yes.As a resident of a "no-gunz" country, this game fulfills my desires for handling a powder based shooting device. If the developer could add the smell of gun powder and lubricant oil the game would be complete.The game:All the variables are randomized at each start. You will spawn with either of the 3 weapons available and the amount of magazines and bullets you spawn with is also randomized. Most of the stages offer more than 4 routes to get past and all of the enemies are spawned randomized.The one thing to bare in mind though is that: The more bullets you find and carry, the more enemies will spawn in the next area. As a kind of progressive difficulty I guess.The story is not that important as you are the receiver of audio tapes carrying an audio tape player. The tapes you find will progress the game and when you have collected 11 tapes, the game is complete. But don't expect to complete the game in the first playthrough.The gun handling is the main concept of the game as each action bound to a button manipulates the gun in one specific way. There's no "R" to reload automatically and watch a prerecorded animation play that lasts 4 seconds, you are the one doing the heavy work.You press one button to: Pull the slide back, eject the magazine, pull the slide catch down or up, activate safety, grab a magazine from your harness, etc.The first hour of the game is probably a learning process but after that, the game is a lovely charming experience of gun porn. It will be satisfactory when you manage to do a speed reload in 2 seconds and shoot a bot coming towards you.Are there ways this game could be better?Absolutely. It could use more textures, mipmapping, bumpmapping, atmospheric soundscapes and more stages and weapons but as a concept of gaming it is complete. I would love to see moouse gestures implemented as a means for the actions that have longer motions. Buttons like safety, slide catch, mag release and cylinder spin can still be button specific, but actions like pulling the slide and manipulating magazines and bullets could be mouse gestures. Hold CTRL to make the mouse button appear and start clicking and dragging.But I'm not afraid that this is the last game with this concept as other games inspired by this is slowly appearing on Steam Greenlight as well as on the web.

												This game is to your average FPS what a flight simulator is to, say, Gradius.Call me crazy, but this is a pretty damn good survival horror game. It gives you just enough of the tools you need to survive and not much more, a foreboding atmosphere, and a threat you can just barely deal with. You're not completely helpless, but you're not some badass dudebro space marine manly man who has everything under control. The pressure is on you--if you get hit even once, you're dead no matter what progress you've made. If you don't make your bullets count, you'll be hard-pressed to find more ammo. A feeling of tension is ever-present.Who needs jump scares when you can put real pressure on the player? This game really puts emphasis on the "survival" in survival horror.

ry 13, 2014
												Receiver can only be described as a gun simulator. The combat is nothing special; right-click to aim with a small deadzone and left-click to fire. But what makes it a notable experiment in video gaming is the act of reloading. It's nothing so simple as pressing R and waiting for an animation to play out; you have to press a button for almost every action involved.When you first spawn in, you need to check your firearm. There are buttons to pull back (and then lock) the slide, toggle the safety, (de-)♥♥♥♥ the hammer, remove the magazine, place the magazine in a specific inventory slot, remove a magazine from a specific inventory slot, holster the firearm, and load individual rounds into magazines.If you can master the art of firing a shot, dropping the mag, holstering the firearm, reloading the magazine, redrawing the firearm, replacing the magazine, and (just for good measure) hitting the bolt release, you'll more than likely get a tingly sensation after doing it. This is hands-on gun porn.The rest of the game is pretty basic; textures are a luxury, geometry is flat and neutral, the atmosphere is eerie in a Deus-Ex way, and the lore behind the recordings is rather interesting. Combat is tense and calculated, much more akin to chess than boxing, but sometimes the rules aren't clear enough to ease your frustration every time you die.In the end, I'd love to see more games like this for more firearms, if only as an instruction tool for people wanting to learn how to use firearms without access to any or proper instruction.7/10 - I came 9mm.

content:
r 18, 2013
												Receiver's an odd game - a rougelike loot-n-shoot with generated levels, but I like it. As a gun nerd myself, the game does a very good job of modeling all the various real-life functions of the Colt M1911A1, Glock 17 w/ full auto mod, and S&W Model 10 pistols. Slides can be manually racked, and held open. You can ♥♥♥♥ the hammer on pistols that have them, and lower them as well. Magazines have to be loaded with individual rounds. You can even engage the safety on the M1911A1 if you really want to!It's also a great way to learn about how to properly handle and operate real life pistols and revolvers, as well.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2013
												Warning: This is an addicting game. The gameplay is not unlike the '-Shock' series, where you're looking for audio tapes whilst trying to avoid and/or get-the-drop-on drones and turrets. The real difference in Reciever is in the shooting/gun mechanics. The gun you have in 'shooter' games is usually little more than a fancy finger that goes 'pew pew' wherever you're pointing it. In Reciever, your weapon is a very realistic *system* with which you must learn to interact, both successfully and quickly, in order to survive combat scenarios. This means knowing how many bullets you have in your clip, replacing a clip when you need to, not dropping bullets by accident as you're trying to refill a clip on the fly. All of this is in your direct control. No random dice-rolls... if you get caught with your pants down, it's on you. It's that direct relation of personal skill and performance that really draws you in. You will die quickly, and often. But each time you load up the game, or 'respawn', the environment is shuffled randomly. Even the equipment you start with is randomized. No two games are the same. And with almost zero load time. Just get killed by a drone that you didn't know was there until it was too late? It's okay, you immediately find yourself in a totally different place with a new weapon(1 of 3 , that I've seen) to familiarize yourself with and the lessons you learned from your previous life still fresh in your memory... now go see how long you live this time!This is a great game and I honestly think every person who's ever played a FPS before should play it. If for no other reason than to gain a little more respect for the weaponry that so many of us have grown to take for granted. It's cheap. It's great. I recommend it.

content:
2, 2015
												I would recommend this game to just about anybody who is a fan of the first-person shooter genre or has any kind of interest in guns. This well crafted gun simulator is, like they say, easy to learn but hard to master. Learning each weapon and how it is operated by muscle memory is fluid and satisfying; I never tired of loading and charging a weapon.The minimalistic presentation of the game environment allows the gun to be the focus of the game, as it should be, but each section in the procedurally generated world has its own challenges and secrets. After some practice you will grow well versed in traversing these environments and scanning them for threats and loot, which brings its own satisfaction.Perhaps the most satisfying of all the game's elements is its actual combat. Enemies come in two types: hovering taser drones and static turrets, both of which can deliver instant and fatal damage to the player. The gameplay here is challenging, but never unfair, and the quick restarts allow you to dive straight back into the game and apply what you've learned from past mistakes. The trial-and-error nature of Receiver's gameplay gives it a visceral and ephemeral feel comparable to that of Hotline Miami, although with a vastly different tone.Like the rest of the game, Receiver's story is delivered in a minimalistic and really quite interpretive style. You are tasked with exploring the world and collecting all eleven casette tapes, which contain a wealth of esoteric knowledge, accessible only to the specially mentally conditioned, known of course as 'receivers'. Despite their monotone delivery, I never really became bored with the tapes even after repeated listens. By the time you have heard all eleven, you will have memorised a great deal of background story information, which gives the feeling that you are a receiver. The casettes mention important story threads such as 'the Threat', 'the Mindkill' and multiple realities with such passing apathy that one is forced to imagine what exactly they entail, making the story that much more interesting. Without so much being left to the imagination, the game's story could not have had nearly the same effect.All told, Receiver is a simple but beautiful game. Its developers set out to create in seven days an engaging and accurate gun simulator with minimalist storytelling and they have succeeded by all measures. Receiver is a cheap buy and well worth a look from a fan of the shooting genre.

content:
er 25, 2015
												Created for the 7-day FPS challenge?That's cute.Publish and do no update to improve your game?Ha, ha, no.-------------------------Let's start with system requirements.- Can you run smoothly with just 2.0 GHz CPU?No.- Can you run smoothly with just 2 GB RAM?No way on earth possible after traveling 5 new zones.- Then why doesn't the developer team change it?They never bother to optimize their game. They let the community to do it for them.Side note: The only time I can accept poorly optimized game if the developer team has attempted to update in good faith but no longer exist. (i.e. Vampire the Masquerade Bloodlines)-------------------------Ok, let's say you can run this game and play it.- What is that? No spare magazine for your 1911?Better restart.- What is that? No tape (The objective to pick up 11 tapes in game) in next room?Better restart.- Not your favorite gun?Better restart.- No bullet / only one or two bullets at the start?Better hope no enemy behind the corner.Oh wait, what am I saying.BETTER RESTART.- Five flying drones in a room?Better U-turn now.If not possible, BETTER RESTART.I understand this is rogue-like, but not having a spare empty magazine and some bullets at the start is asking players to restart endlessly.------------------------Now, gun handling mechanics.This is only interesting mechanic in this game.- Want to know how to load bullets into magazine like in real life?Sure.- Want to know reload your gun?Sure.- Want to know the steps to fire your gun?Sure.While gun handling mechanics are great,Cons > Pros------------------------TL;DRThis is one of those games that the developer team decided to publish their game and do nothing to improve it.Wait on sale if you want to try gun handling mechanics.For other reasons, No.

number of helpful: 14 of 29 people (48%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
er 13, 2015
												I like the idea of it. I like the idea of a game where you actually have to go through all the motions of maintaining your weapon, e.g. opening the chamber, extracting the empty casings, loading the new bullets, closing the chamber, pulling the hammer, etc. There is something tactile about it that is very satisfying.The thing that really kills it for me, though, is that the different styles of gun lead to completely different control schemes. Sometimes equipping the flashlight is the 2 key, but sometimes it is the 1 key. In one round, tapping Z causes you to load more bullets into the empty chambers you're examining, but in the next round, pressing Z will make you drop the clip you're examining onto the ground (even if it's full). There are too many buttons doing too many things as it is, but then when the game shifts them around on you every round, it only compounds the problem. Those who are patient enough to go through the pain of memorizing all this may not have a bad time, but it is a major hurdle to the enjoyment of the game.The point at which I quit the game though was when I loaded a new round and the randomization placed me inside a room with a flying turret directly behind me. Literally, the round started, I heard a gunshot, and the round was over. I know roguelikes are super into busting the player's balls with randomization, but that seemed a bit steep.In short, I love the idea, but I don't think I like the execution.
